Question: What colour can precede Panther, Widow, Canary, Adam and Bolt to give the names of notable comic book characters?

In 2002, who became the first African American woman to win the Pulitzer Prize for Drama for her play Topdog/Underdog? Her 2014 play Father Comes Home From the Wars, Parts 1, 2 & 3 was also shortlisted for the Pulitzer Prize.

Answer: The Barber of Seville (Il barbiere di Siviglia)

Known as the Genesis in North America, the Mega Drive was a games console made from 1988 to 1997 by which video games company?

What name beginning with P is given in linguistics to a grammatically simplified means of communication that develops between two or more groups that do not have a language in common? It may take vocabulary and grammar from several languages and is not considered to amount to a full language itself.

Name either of those other DJs, one born in Bolton and the other in Manchester.

The novel The Sorrows of Young Werther and the two-part drama Faust are works by which giant of German literature?

This instrument is sometimes considered the precursor to the European lute, and its Persian equivalent is called the barbat.

The existence of this concept is the first of Buddhism's Four Noble Truths and the religion teaches that a person can break free of this concept by following the Eightfold Path.

What name beginning with C is given in linguistics to a stable natural language that develops from simplifying and mixing other languages to form a new one? His obituary described him as the last lion comique.

Which Asian politician was the third female winner of Time Person of the Year, after Wallis Simpson and Queen Elizabeth II in 1952, in 1986 – the year she led a popular revolution became President of her nation?
Often consisting of bait such as an earthworm threaded on a needle then inserted into holes or crannies with a long pole, what type of fish hook is often used to catch eels by anglers?
The Lauberhorn mountain, which hosts one of the most prestigious races in the Ski World Cup, lies between Grindelwald and which Swiss ski resort?
The pinniped clade consists of seals and which other semi-aquatic mammals distinguished by their large tusks? The elephant seal is the only pinniped bigger than these mammals.
A famous 1945 photo by Joe Rosenthal depicts US Marines raising the Stars and Stripes on which Japanese island, the subject of a 1945 battle which was also the focus of a 2006 Clint Eastwood film?
Who was the first American winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics, doing so in 1970? His works include the best-selling economics textbook of all time, Economics: An Introductory Analysis.
The US Triple Crown consists of the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes and which other race held in June?
Sci-fi writer Neil Stephenson acts as as adviser to which American privately funded aerospace manufacturer and sub-orbital spaceflight services company founded by Jeff Bezos in 2000?
Which Briton of Italian ancestry was Principal Conductor at the Scottish Chamber Orchestra from 2009 to 2018, and since 2014 has been Music Director at Glyndebourne Festival Opera?
China has attracted international condemnation for its treatment of which Muslim-majority ethnic group which lives in the Xinjiang region of China, in the Taklamakan Desert?
Which US state joined the union on 4 March 1791, the first to join that was not one of the original thirteen?

Following the death of Leonard Rossiter, Tripper's Day was, despite its poor reviews, re-imagined as Slinger's Day. Which entertainer and presenter who died in 2017 aged 89 played the title character Cecil Slinger?
Which large British pub chain owns several pubs called The Moon Under Water, including one on Leicester Square?
What exercise fitness programme was created by the Colombian dancer and choreographer Alberto Perez and was originally called Rumbacize?

Which mythical creature is the Persian equivalent of a sphinx and is usually depicted with the head of a human, body of a lion and a tail of venomous spines similar to porcupine quills?
Clad in a red and black striped top, what is the alliterative forename of the Beano character, described as "The Minx", who is a tomboyish girl known for mischievous behaviour?

Which shoe brand, only founded in 2002, owns exclusive rights to manufacturer a resin called Croslite which it uses to make its namesake foam clogs? Its revenue passed $1bn per annum in 2017.

Who was the last Irish male golfer to win a Golf Major, winning the Open in 2019? It is so far his only Major.
In November 2022, the UN COP 27 conference on climate change took place in which Egyptian city and holiday resort on the Sinai Peninsula, a popular conference venue?
In ice hockey, when a player is serving a penalty and their team are at a numerical disadvantage, the team are said to be in what state, abbreviated to SH?

Deriving from an indigenous word for 'ball' or 'game', what is the two-word name for traditional Indigenous Australian football games played at gatherings and celebrations by sometimes more than 100 players?

What is the name of the narrow strip of Afghanistan that extends to the Chinese border, separating Tajikistan from Pakistan-administered Kashmir? Historically, it acted as a buffer zone between Russian and British-controlled territory.
In Greek myth, what does Prometheus steal from the gods in order to give to humankind?

Which Swedish food brand, founded in 1945, is known for its ready meals, particularly including its crispy pancakes, as well as involvement in a scandal where horsemeat was used as a lasagne filling? It sponsored Grimsby Town from 1979–84.

In 2022, which US rapper embarked on their first solo concert world tour since 2018 for the release of their new album, Mr Morale and the Big Steppers? Their earlier albums include Good Kid, M.A.A.D City.

Which principle, used in determining electron configuration of atoms of ions, states that electrons will fill subshells of lowest available energy first? The word comes from a German phrase meaning 'building up'.

As well as eight records and a book, a castaway on Desert Island Discs may select one other item which must be inanimate and of no help in enabling them to escape. What name does the show use to describe that item?
Which French term describes the special move in chess that occurs when a pawn captures a horizontally adjacent enemy pawn that has just made an initial two-square advance?
Roy Jenkins won a Whitbread Award for his biography of which Liberal Prime Minister? He was the oldest to ever hold the position and is known for his rivalry with Benjamin Disraeli.

In finance, what name is given to a derivative where two parties agree to exchange cash flows from one asset for cash flows from another? Typically these might involve fixed and floating interest rates, or currencies.

Many US Acts of Congress have names that are backronyms – that is, where a word is chosen to name the act and lawmakers come up with something plausible for which it stands. In the 2001 PATRIOT Act, for what was the second T said to stand?
If the S stands for 'syndrome', for what does IB stand in the initialism IBS when referring to a disorder of the digestive system with symptoms including bloating and abdominal pain?
Which US writer was nominated for the Booker Prize in 2021 for her book No One Is Talking About This? She also wrote the 2017 memoir Priestdaddy.

Which bridge, when opened, carried the A90 across its namesake body of water? It now carries the A9000, while the nearby Queensferry Crossing now carries the upgraded M90. The name of the body of water is sufficient.
Which word for a very wealthy individual comes from a Japanese translation meaning either 'Great Prince' or 'High Commander'?
What name for a sleeveless jacket or body warmer comes from the French for waistcoat or vest? This word appears in the name of a populist protest movement in France.
Which Italian architect (1508–1580) emphasised symmetry, perspective and classical influences in his work and gives his name to a school of architecture of the 17th and 18th centuries?
In thermodynamics, an isochoric process is one that occurs at constant values of which property? Boyle's Law relates the pressure of a gas to this property.

Which 2017 film, directed by Feras Fayyad, follows the search-and-rescue missions of the White Helmets during the Syrian Civil War? It was nominated for Best Documentary Feature at the 90th Academy Awards.
Which Italian-born football agent, who died in 2022, was famous for representing players such as Paul Pogba and Erling Haaland?
The Declaration of Sentiments was a document signed by 100 delegates of which women's rights convention held in the namesake location in New York State in 1848?
Inspired by a Breton legend that tells of a mysterious building in the sea off the coast of the island of Ys [EESE], which composer wrote the 1910 piano prelude The Sunken Cathedral?

What is the name of the Indonesian sweet soy sauce that has a darker colour and more viscous consistency than normal soy sauce, and a more molasses-like flavour? It is widely used in dishes like nasi goreng and mie goreng.
Which iconic cartoon character performs Hungarian Rhapsody No. 2 by Franz Liszt in the animated short Rhapsody Rabbit? This character also parodied Wagnerian opera in another cartoon.
Ninox is a genus of what bird? Many of the bird species within this genus are called boobooks.

Fought in 1937–38 in its namesake city in Aragon, which battle is regarded as the military turning point of the Spanish Civil War? Franco's nationalists eventually retook the city from the Republicans.
Which Scottish four-time world snooker champion – who won the title in 1998, 2007, '09, and '11 – is nicknamed 'the Wizard of Wishaw'?
The forthcoming horror film subtitled Blood and Honey is inspired by, and named for, which much-loved character from a children's book, who first appeared in 1926?
Which village near Bideford in north Devon is the only settlement in the British Isles to contain an exclamation mark in its name?

In finance, what name is given to a derivative that gives one party the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell an asset to another party? Calls and puts are the two principal types of this derivative.
Another US Act of Congress with a backronymic name was the 2020 CARES Act, which provided a $2.2 trillion economic stimulus. For what was the C in its name said to stand?

Which German term describes the situation in chess when a player is at a disadvantage because of their obligation to make a move – that is to say, when any legal move will worsen their position?
William Hague won a British Book Award for his biography of which Tory Prime Minister? He was the youngest to ever hold the position and was known for his rivalry with Charles James Fox.

In some versions of the Prometheus myth, he moulds humankind from what substance? In the Book of Daniel, Nebuchadnezzar has a dream about a statue with feet made of this substance, which has led to an idiom meaning a character flaw.

Also known as the Chicken's Neck, what is the name of the narrow strip of land in India that separates the seven states of northwest India from the rest of that country? It is also the name of West Bengal's third largest city, which sits within it.

Which English four-time world snooker champion – who won the title in 2014,'16, '17 and '21 – is nicknamed 'the Jester from Leicester'?

What is the name of the Indonesian chilli sauce or paste made with chilli peppers and other ingredients which may include shrimp paste, garlic, ginger and shallot? It features in dishes such as ikan goreng and ayam goreng.

Which Soviet composer wrote the score for a comedy film titled in English as Lieutenant Kijé? The best-known extract from the score is the Troika, which has come to be associated with Christmas.

Which town on the island of Uvea is the largest town and capital of Wallis and Futuna?

Answer: John Quincy Adams or Andrew Jackson
Question: Senator for South Carolina and defender of slavery John C. Calhoun served as Vice President under two different presidents. Name either of them.

The meaning of which English word is debated between traditionalists, who claim it can only be used to refer to keeping ones thoughts to oneself, and others who observe that it is commonly used as a synonym for "reluctance"? You may give its noun or adjectival form.

Known for addressing taboo subjects in her stand-up comedy, this comedian has also appeared in films like Wreck It Ralph and School of Rock, and she impersonated Rivers on Saturday Night Live.

Which Soviet composer wrote the score for a film titled in English as The Gadfly, based on the novel of the same name by Ethel Voynich? The best-known extract from the score is the Romance, which features a lyrical violin solo.
Nike released two sets of sneakers called the Air Yeezy between 2009 and '14, their first collaboration with a non-sportsman. Yeezy is a nickname for which US rapper, record producer and businessman?

Born Daisy Baker, which US actress (1882–1965) is best remembered for appearing in seven Marx Brothers films including Duck Soup and A Night at the Opera? Groucho Marx called her "practically the fifth Marx brother".

Which English cheddar cheese brand, the UK's leading brand, saw a 15% decline in sales in 2023? You would pay about £6 for a 550 gram slab of this cheese, whose name reflects its origins in Wells, Somerset.

Sergio Garcia was ineligible to play in this year's Ryder Cup due to joining the breakaway LIV tour. Another such player is which Brit, known as a Ryder Cup specialist for his 15 win and 8 loss record and also for his garish dress sense?

Which thermodynamic cycle replaces the isothermal steps in the Carnot cycle with isobaric ones, and is closely approximated by steam turbines? It is named after a Scottish polymath who, like Lord Kevlin, is considered a founding contributor of thermodynamics and developed a temperature scale.
In the United States, most states are subdivided into counties, but what is the equivalent in Alaska? Like parish, this name is a type of political division sometimes found in the UK.
What Levantine dish is made of lamb cooked in a sauce of fermented dried yogurt and served with rice or bulgur? Its name comes from the term 'large tray' in Arabic.
What word completes this Muhammad Ali poem before his third fight with Joe Frazier: "It's gonna be a chilla, and a killa, and a thrilla, when I fight the Gorilla in ..."?
Another of the nine senses humans are often argued to possess is equilibrioception, the scientific name for the sense of what? Many circus performers have a very acute form of this sense.

In English law a person has committed the civil wrong of negligence if (among other things) they breach an obligation imposed on people and companies to avoid causing foreseeable harm to those around them. What three-word term is given to that obligation?
Which spin-off from Happy Days followed the lives of the two title characters as they moved from Milwaukee to Chicago to start a music career? Erin Moran and Scott Baio starred as the titular duo.
Akira Kurosawa's film Ikiru was partially inspired by which 1886 Leo Tolstoy novella which tells the story of a magistrate's search for contentment after he realises that he is dying?
A work by which American artist held the record for most expensive by a living artist until beaten by Jasper Johns? He is best known for his stainless steel balloon animal sculptures.
In Hinduism, which member of the Trimurti, the trinity of supreme gods, has a name beginning with V and is known as the Preserver?
What six-letter word of Hindi origin is given to a platform on the back of an elephant? A mahout may ride on one of these, perhaps with wealthy tourists.
Which YouTube series sees Sean Evans interview famous people while they work their way through a series of increasingly spicy chicken wings?
Which Sanskrit word, roughly translating into English as 'reverence to you' is a common form of greeting in Hindu communities, often accompanied by a bow?

Which equation, named after the Russian who derived it from the Born–Landé equation, can be used to estimate the lattice energy of an ionic crystal that is experimentally difficult to determine? This equation features a namesake constant symbolised K.
Which Barcelona born journalist writes for Spanish football newspaper Diario AS and is a regular on BBC Radio 5 Live's Euro Leagues show?
Typically portrayed as a servant who's in love with the title character, Buttons is a character in which pantomime?

Peter the Great and Peter III were succeeded as Emperor by their wives, who both bore what name? The second of these was known as 'the Great' and is regarded as one of Russia's most significant monarchs.
Clovis, who in the 6th Century AD became the first king to unite the Frankish tribes under one ruler, is considered to be the founder of which dynasty, which ruled the Franks until 751?

The King Fahd Causeway joins Saudi Arabia to which island nation which lies in the Persian Gulf? The border is on the artificial Passport Island which contains a McDonalds outlet each side of the border.
Sometimes sold under the names Prilosec and Losec, which proton pump inhibitor used to treat gastrointestinal reflux and stomach ulcers is the third most prescribed drug in England?

In a short story by Jorge Luis Borges, what is the name of the eccentric French writer and polymath who attempts to immerse himself so deeply in Don Quixote that he is able to "recreate" it line by line in the original 17th century Spanish?
Which Cumbrian team were promoted to the Football League for the first time since 1972 when they won the National League in 2020?
Coloured lavender and with a body that is half human and half octopus, what is the name of the sea witch who is the principal antagonist in Disney's The Little Mermaid?
Which saxophonist founded his namesake Jazz club on Frith Street in Soho in 1959?

What name is given to any accumulation of unconsolidated debris that occurs in both currently and formerly glaciated regions, and has been previously carried along by a glacier or ice sheet? This can come in 'lateral' and 'terminal' varieties.

Which nickel-iron alloy, also known generically as FeNi36, takes its name from the fact it has a uniquely low coefficient of thermal expansion? The discovery of this alloy earned Charles Édouard Guillaume a Nobel Prize.
Which Las Vegas pop rock band released the songs Radioactive, Demons, Sucker for Pain and I Bet My Life, all of which reached the UK top 40, but never reached the top 10?

Which of the African Great Lakes, located on the borders of the Democratic Republic of Congo and Rwanda, is the eighth-largest in Africa and one of three African lakes known to undergo "limnic eruptions" of dissolved carbon dioxide and methane from the lake?
Which attempt to found the first permanent English settlement in North America became known as the 'Lost Colony' after it was found deserted in 1590?
Monsieur de Treville is introduced as the captain of which company of soldiers, the title characters in perhaps the most famous work of Alexandre Dumas?
Which actress who won back-to-back Best Actress Awards at the BAFTAs in 1959 and 1960 for her roles in the films Ask Any Girl and The Apartment is the sister of the actor Warren Beatty?

Which radio station was Britain's first licenced commercial radio station when it began broadcasting in October 1973? Nick Ferrari and James O'Brien are among motormouths who present on this station which is based, at its name suggests, in the West End.
In 1981, which British alpine skier achieved a surprise second place in the World Cup downhill at Val Gardena, coming within 0.11 seconds of the winner?
Which daughter of King Aeetes assisted Jason in retrieving the Golden Fleece before abandoning her native Colchis and marrying Jason?
In 2019, Colgate was by some way the most popular brand of toothpaste in the UK. Which brand owned by GlaxoSmithKline and aimed at people with sensitive teeth came second?

The cult US sitcom Police Squad! was adapted into which series of crime spoof comedy films? Priscilla Presley, OJ Simpson and George Kennedy appeared in these films despite not starring in the sitcom.
In addition to the two NBA championships he won as a player, which basketball coach led the Chicago Bulls and the LA Lakers to a combined total of eleven championship wins between 1987 and 2011?
What six letter word precedes "dam" in the name of an enclosure built within a body of water to enable the water within to be pumped out, creating a safe and dry working area?
There is more to German impresario Frank Farian than Boney M and Milli Vanilli. He managed which disco act who had 1970s top ten hits with One Way Ticket and I Can't Stand The Rain?
Which London wholesale bank, whose business in dealing in bills of exchange led to it being called "the banker's banker", collapsed in 1866 owing £11 million, causing a broader banking crisis?

What does the FTP stand for in FTPA, a statute introduced in 2011, which for the first time stipulates UK General Elections at five-yearly intervals unless otherwise agreed (as occurred in 2017 and 2019)? The current Government has pledged to repeal the act.
The Sharks, who won the Rugby Union Premiership for the only time in 2005-06, play in which town in Greater Manchester which features in their name?
Which 1978-'79 LWT sitcom, written by David Renwick and Andrew Marshall, was an attempt to transfer which their Radio Four comedy series The Burkiss Way to the small screen?
In which opera does the title character pray for strength in the soprano aria 'Vissi d'arte' shortly before stabbing the chief of police?

The first law of thermodynamics is a version of the principle that what property beginning with E must always be conserved? Perpetual motion machines which purport to create work without the input of this property violate the first law.

During Donald Trump's second impeachment trial, Republican Congressman Jaime Herrera Beutler revealed that Trump had ignored a request from which politician to "forcefully call off the riot"? This politician has served as House Minority Leader since 2019.
In economics, what word beginning with U is a concept used to model the worth or value that a person attaches to something?
What term is given to the stage in baking when the dough is given time to rest and rise before baking? Home bakers may use a basket called a banneton for this stage.

Which contemporary of Johannes Vermeer painted The Courtyard of a House in Delft, which is on show in London's National Gallery? Like many of his paintings it shows a domestic scene and light coming through an open doorway.
Which North Yorkshire team were promoted to the Football League for the first time in their history when they won the 2020 National League play-off final?
An arrogant huntsman who attempts to murder the Beast, his rival for the attentions of Belle, what is the name of the principal antagonist in Disney's Beauty and the Beast?
The world famous 'Birdland' jazz club is named after which legendary saxophonist?

Deriving from the Irish for "littlest ridge", what name is given to an elongated hill in the shape of an inverted spoon or half-buried egg formed by glacial ice acting on underlying unconsolidated glacial moraine?
Pepin the Short, who overthrew the Merovingian Childeric III in 751 AD, was the first ruler of which royal dynasty, which went on to rule the Franks from then until 888?

Saudi Arabia has threatened to construct the Salwa Canal along its border with which neighbouring state, an oil-rich country lying on a small peninsula with which Saudi has been on bad terms since 2017? If constructed, the canal would render this state an island.

Sometimes sold under the name Glucophage, which drug that increases insulin sensitivity is used to treat Type 2 diabetes and polycystic ovary syndrome and is among the ten most prescribed drugs in England?

In a short story by Jorge Luis Borges, what is the name of the teenage Uruguayan boy who, after falling off a horse and receiving a bad head injury, acquires a prodigious memory, which turns out to be a curse as much as a blessing?
In Alexandre Dumas' novel The Three Musketeers, the musketeers' rivals are a company of guards which are loyal to which real-life clergyman and statesman, an advisor to Louis XIII?
Which actress who was Oscar nominated for Best Actress for her roles in the films The Sterile Cuckoo and Cabaret (winning the latter) is the daughter of the actress Judy Garland?

In October 1973, LBC beat which other commercial radio station owned by Global Media and Entertainment by one week to become Britain's first licenced commercial station? This pop music station nowadays has twelve regional stations and, as its name suggests, is headquartered in the West End of London.
Konrad Bartelski's second place remained the highest World Cup placing by a British skier until 2017 when it was equalled by which man in the Kitzbuhel World Cup Slalom?
Which copper-nickel alloy takes its name from its low temperature coefficient of electrical resistance? It was developed by Edward Weston, who later developed Manganin, which has similar properties.
Which Las Vegas pop rock band released the songs Nine in The Afternoon, I Write Sins, Not Tragedies and But It's Better If You Do, all of which reached the UK top 40, but never reached the top 10?

Name either of the other two lakes in Africa, both located in Cameroon, which undergo limnic eruptions in the same way as Lake Kivu. Both erupted in this fashion in the 1980s, one killing almost 2,000 local people.

A longer-lasting English settlement in North America was which settlement founded in 1607, which served as colonial capital until 1699? With Williamsburg and Yorktown it forms the Historic Triangle of Colonial Virginia.

Similar to a cofferdam, what seven letter word refers to another structure used to provide a safe and dry working environment in water? It can be open like a cofferdam or fully enclosed, and this word also features in another name for decompression sickness.
German impresario Frank Farian managed which US pop group who enjoyed a major UK hit in 1996 with a cover of the La Bouche song Where Do You Go?

At one time the largest bank in Austria-Hungary, which Vienna bank collapsed in 1931, spreading the Great Depression in Europe and in later years providing Adolf Hitler and the Nazis with a propaganda opportunity?

Before the Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011, a General Election could be called whenever the Prime Minister advised the monarch to exercise what powers? Beginning with P and often preceded with Royal, the scope of these powers was at issue in the Miller case, decided by the Supreme Court in 2017.
According to Hesiod's Theogony, Medea was the niece of which enchantress? Odysseus and his men live with her for a year on her island of Aeaea during their return from Troy.
In 2020, Business Insider rated a "Cool Mint" product made by which brand as the best available mouthwash? This brand is owned by Johnson & Johnson and named after a Scottish surgeon.
Which Canadian actor played central character Frank Drebin in both Police Squad! and The Naked Gun films?

Which point guard won three of his five NBA championships whilst playing under Phil Jackson at the Chicago Bulls? As coach of the Golden State Warriors he has added a further three championships in 2015, 2017 and 2018.

Ultimately a written testimony from Jaime Herrera Beutler was submitted as evidence during Donald Trump's second impeachment trial. This followed an attempt to subpoena her by which congressman, who acted as the lead impeachment manager?
In economics, what P refers to the order that a person gives to alternatives, based on his or her assessment of their relative utility?
What term is used in baking for the ratio of water to flour? Given as a percentage, a higher number for this measure results in a stickier dough that may be used for a more rustic loaf.

Which genre painter of the Dutch Golden Age painter A Burgomaster of Delft and his daughter during his time living in the city. Many of his paintings show chaotic representations of everyday life, such as his Feast of Saint Nicholas.
The Saints, who won the Rugby Union Premiership for the only time in 2013-14, play in which large town generally considered to be in the East Midlands?
Which 1986-'88 LWT sitcom, written by David Renwick and Andrew Marshall, was at the fictional Daily Crucible, which has just been taken over by media mogul Terence Rathbone?
In which Bellini opera does the titular priestess pray for peace in the soprano aria 'Casta Diva'?

The second law of thermodynamics states that what property beginning with E cannot decrease over time? Perpetual motion machines which purport to spontaneously convert thermal energy into work violate the second law.
Which of C.S. Lewis' Chronicles of Narnia, the penultimate to be written, is regarded by Lewis' readership and by publishers Harper Collins as the first chronologically?
Which French composer's film scores include The Grand Budapest Hotel and The Shape of Water?
One of the city's most popular attractions and reputed to be the largest daytime market in Europe, which open-air market in Amsterdam is named after a 17th century painter?
What name is given to the triangular hat, made from sheep's wool, which is popular in Afghanistan, and was worn by Hamid Karzai?
Captain James Cook was killed by natives in which island group in 1779?
Petrology is a branch of geology studying what items and how they form?
Hosting 53 Test Matches since 1930, the Kensington Oval is a cricket venue situated in which Caribbean capital city?
The name of which calico textile, with a name derived from Hindi, is one of the few English six-letter words all of the letters of which are in alphabetical order?
Which port city is found at the western terminus of the M62 Motorway?
In Wikipedia, what 14 letter word is used for a page which lists a number of topics that all relate to a single word, e.g. listing the element, planet and god below the heading Mercury?

Answer: Montparnasse (accept Mount Parnassus but prompt on Parnassus)
Question: The artist's model and muse born Alice Prin was better known as Kiki de … which Parisian artistic district on the left bank of the Seine, whose name is a translation of the name of the home of the Muses in Greek mythology?

Which 1988 documentary by Errol Morris concerns the story of the unjustly convicted death row prisoner Randall Dale Adams and is named after a phrase for the police? The name contains four words, the first of which is "The".
Spain won the 2010 FIFA World Cup but which European team, who were knocked out in the group stages, beat them in their first match in the tournament?
What colour is the a in the eBay logo and the second o in the Google logo?
The decisive battle of Alexander the Great's invasion of the Persian Achaemenid Empire, what was the name of the battle of 331 BC which took place near modern-day Erbil in Kurdistan?
An influence on Werner von Braun, which German-Romanian rocket scientist wrote The Rocket into Interplanetary Space and Ways to Spaceflight?
Ratified in 1865, what number amendment to the US Constitution abolished slavery?
In cell biology, which component of the cell contains the material within a living cell, excluding the cell nucleus?
Since it was reintroduced to the Olympics in 1988, which player is the only male player to win back to back Olympic gold medals in the men's single tennis, doing so in 2012 and 2016?
A Kachera is a special undergarment which is one of the Five Ks which form articles of faith of which religion?
The religious works The Protecting Veil and Song for Athene, and the cantata The Whale are works by which British composer (1944-2013)?
Often considered one of the worst UK sitcoms of all time, what was the name of the series which ran from 1984 to 1985 and featured Robin Askwith as a randy milkman?
What name was given to the Native American belief system that developed in the 19th century and claimed that the title activity would reunite the living with the spirits of the dead?
A classic Mornay sauce is made by adding gruyere cheese to which of the mother sauces of French cuisine?
Doing so in 1971 for the Dallas Cowboys, who is the only player to win the American Football Superbowl MVP while playing on the losing side?
Which American popular mathematics writer (1914-2010) authored Scientific American's Mathematical Games column for 25 years, as well as writing over 100 books on maths and puzzles?
Taking place in Sussex, Jack Cade led a popular revolt against the government of England during the reign of which King? Name and regnal number are needed.
On the periodic table, chromium and tungsten are located directly above and below which element beginning with M?
The flag of which historic county of England depicts a white bear holding a ragged staff on a red background?
The evocative 1973 "boy on a bike" advert for Hovis depicted a boy wheeling his bicycle down Gold Hill in which Dorset village?

Answer: Uncle Tom's Cabin, or Life Among the Lowly
Question: The cruel slave-owner Simon Legree is the principal antagonist of which 1852 American classic novel?
Taking their name from a German city, which American band's only UK number one was Take My Breath Away?

It sounds rather like a legal term but has a different derivation: what name is given to an event in which Australian Aborigines interact with the Dreamtime (their religious belief system) through dance, music and costume?
Which Canadian composer's film scores include The Lord of the Rings trilogy and The Hobbit?
The operas The Exterminating Angel, The Tempest and Powder Her Face are works by which British composer (1971-)?
Which American cognitive scientist (1945-) took over Martin Gardner's Mathematical Games column in 1981, renaming it Metamagical Themas (an anagram of Mathematical Games)?
In 1988 which tennis player became the only person to win a "Golden Slam", when they won all four Grand Slam events as well as the Olympic women's gold medal?
Pedology is a branch of geology studying what substance and how it forms? Edaphology is another branch of geology studying the same substance.
Ratified in 1933, what number amendment to the US Constitution abolished prohibition?
Which film director directed the 1973 "boy on a bike" advert for Hovis? His other advertising work includes the famous "1984" advert for Apple Macintosh.
Ahab, the demented captain of the Pequod, is the principal antagonist of which 1851 American classic novel?
Temple garments are special undergarments worn by adherents of which religion, founded by Joseph Smith in the 1820s?
The flag of which historic county of England depicts three black pears on a shield against a wavy green and blue background?

Which 2003 documentary by Errol Morris is subtitled Eleven Lessons from the Life of Robert S. Macnamara, and is named after a military phrase depicting the difficulty of making decisions in combat? The name contains four words, the first of which is "The".
Taking place in Norfolk, Robert Kett led a popular revolt, largely against the enclosure of land, during the reign of which King? Name and regnal number are needed.
A classic Supreme sauce is made by adding reduced mushroom liquor to which of the mother sauces of French cuisine?
Doing so in 1960 for the New York Yankees, who is the only player to win the Baseball World Series MVP while playing on the losing side?
An influence on Sergei Korolev, which Russian rocket scientist wrote the influential article Exploration of Cosmic Space by Means of Reaction Devices?

Answer: Port of Spain, Trinidad and Tobago
Question: Hosting 61 Test Matches since 1930, the Queens Park Oval is a cricket venue situated in which Caribbean capital city?
In cell biology, which organelle is called the powerhouse of the cell and produces 90% of the chemical energy that cells need to survive?
Ferdinand Magellan was killed in a battle on the island of Mactan in which island group and modern day nation, in 1521?
In Wikipedia, what 8 letter word precedes "needed" in request by an editor for a statement in an article to be verified by reference to an external source?
One of the city's most popular attractions, which large park in Amsterdam contains an open-air theatre and is named after a 17th century Dutch playwright?

Answer: Up The Elephant and Around the Castle
Question: Often considered one of the worst UK sitcoms of all time, what was the name of the series which ran from 1983 and 1985 which featured Jim Davison as an apparently loveable womanising rogue? It went on to spawn the spin off Home James.
Bree, who can talk, and Shasta, are the title characters of which of C.S. Lewis's Chronicles of Narnia, which like The Magician's Nephew was written out of chronological order?
What colour is the y in the eBay logo and the l in the Google logo?
Alexander the Great defeated King Porus of the Paurava Kingdom at which 326 BC battle fought on the banks of the river nowadays known as the Jhelum?
Which cap in the shape of a truncated cone is commonly worn in Indonesia and Malaysia, including by leaders such as Sukarno?

Due to Spain losing to Switzerland, which southern hemisphere team, who were eliminated in the group stages having drawn all their games, thus became the only country to not lose a match in the 2010 FIFA World Cup?
On the periodic table, zinc and mercury are located directly above and below which element beginning with C?
Kiki de Montparnasse modelled for the 1924 work Ingres' Violin by which artist and photographer?

The name of which medical procedure involving the extraction of cells from tissue to determine the presence or extent of disease is one of the few English six-letter words all of the letters of which are in alphabetical order?
Which city on the Humber is found at the eastern terminus of the M62 motorway?
Taking their name from a continent, which Swedish band's only UK number one was The Final Countdown?
Express is the budget chain for which hotel brand? This brand, owned by the IHG Group, was named after a 1942 film musical that featured White Christmas on its soundtrack.
Formula One's Canadian Grand Prix is held at the Circuit Gilles Villeneuve in which city?
The Belle Stars had their first UK top 20 hit in 1983 with a cover of which song, which originally reached the top ten in 1965 for Shirley Ellis?

Which Swiss psychologist is known for his work on child development, having proposed a four-stage theory for their cognitive development? The discipline of genetic epistemology is based on the theories of this author of The Moral Judgment of the Child.
What name is given to a series of nuclear fusion reactions, commonly occurring in the centres of stars, through which three helium-4 nuclei fuse together to form a nucleus of carbon-12?
The story of David and Goliath is told in which book of the Old Testament?

In what type of facility in ancient Roman cities would you find rooms called the tepidarium, caldarium and frigidarium? A well-preserved example is located in the English city known to the Romans as Aquae Sulis.
Who were Fearless in the title of a 1967 British horror film directed by and starring Roman Polanski and also starring Sharon Tate?
Born in Mexico City in 1920, who played Mr Rourke, the enigmatic overseer on the TV show Fantasy Island? He would also find fame playing a classic sci-fi villain.
In which northern English county did the popular revolt known as the Pilgrimage of Grace begin in 1536? The revolt's leader, Robert Aske, hailed from this county's town of Selby.
When Brian Lara broke the record for highest individual test score in 1994, he broke which player's record score of 365 not out, which had been scored for the West Indies against Pakistan in 1958?
The name of which English county follows 'Russ in' in the name of a prominent anti-Tory Twitter account run by Russ Jones?
Of the eight successful applicants for city status in 2022, which city in the Falkland Islands has by far the smallest population, coming in at just under 2,500?
In which 1970s film musical would you find the songs Sweet Transvestite, Dammit Janet and The Time Warp?
Which former war artist won a silver medal for painting at the 1928 Olympics? She is known for her depictions of marginalised groups and her Self-Portrait with Nude.
Which German naturalist who explored Alaska and Kamchatka gives his name to species including a sea eagle, a sea lion, an eider and a jay?

Which mountain on their border is the highest point in both Albania and North Macedonia? It is one of just five mountains to be the highest point in two countries and the only one in Europe beside Mont Blanc.

Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau is well known for his recordings of Schubert song cycles made alongside which English piano accompanist? Widely regarded as one of the greatest accompanists ever, this pianist is also known for his collaborations with Elisabeth Schwarzkopf and Victoria de Los Ángeles.
Which German author is known for his works including The Sorrows of Young Werther, Wilhelm Meister's Apprenticeship and Faust?
In a right-angled triangle, what trigonometric function may be expressed the ratio of the length of the side adjacent to the angle being measured, to the length of the hypotenuse?

In January 2023, which radio DJ announced that he was leaving his mid-morning show on BBC Radio 2, which he had presented since 1992? The show features the quiz PopMaster, which this DJ will take to Greatest Hits Radio.
Which Conservative politician threatened to sue The Sunday Mirror in 1964 when it alluded to his relationship with Ronnie Kray?
Which puzzle platform game series, released by Valve, follows the silent protagonist Chell as she is challenged by an artificial intelligence named GLaDOS?

The restauranteur Ado Campeol is often credited with inventing which Italian dessert in 1972? It consists of ladyfinger biscuits dipped in coffee, mascarpone, eggs, sugar, and cocoa and has a name that comes from the Italian for 'pick me up'.
The namesake 'number', or 'constant', of which Italian scientist is equal to the number of atoms or molecules in one mole of any given substance?

Which novel by Han Kang, first published in Korean and translated into English by Deborah Smith, won the International Booker Prize in 2016? It tells the story of Yeong-hye, a woman whose life begins to unravel after she has a dream about animal slaughter.

Which city of around 70,000 people located 90 kilometres north of Donetsk has been the subject of intense fighting since November 2022 when Russian forces were reinforced by units redeployed from the Kherson front? The front between this city and Soledar has been an important recent focus in the war, with positional trench warfare destroying much of this city.
In 2011, Asif Kapadia won the BAFTA for Best Documentary for his film about which legendary Brazilian Formula One driver, who died in 1994?
What alliterative two-word name is often given to the flower Gypsophila when used in floristry? The name reflects the delicateness of the tiny white flowers.
Which discipline of sport climbing involves competitors trying to find the solution to a short route or problem without the use of a harness or ropes?
Which American indie-rock band whose lead songwriter is Julian Casablancas won the 2001 NME Album of the Year award for their debut album, Is This It?
What name is shared by the state capital of Delaware and a town in southern England?
Of the eight successful applicants for city status in 2022, which city on the Isle of Man has the second smallest population, despite being ten times the size of Stanley?
In which 1970s film musical would you find the songs Wilkommen, Tomorrow Belongs to Me and Mein Herr?

Which Irish former war artist also competed for Great Britain at the 1928 Olympics? As well as his war paintings such as Dead Germans in a Trench, he is known for his depictions of upper-class Edwardian life and for his many fanciful self-portraits.
Which German naturalist who explored central Asia gives his name to species including a cat, a sandgrouse, a fish eagle and two species of warbler?
Born in Nazi-occupied Paris in 1943, who played Tattoo, Mr Rourke's assistant in the TV show Fantasy Island? He had previously been the sidekick to a Bond villain.
In which eastern English county did the popular revolt known as Kett's Rebellion begin in 1549? The revolt's leader, Robert Kett, hailed from this county's town of Wymondham.

Garfield Sobers' record individual test score of 365 not out broke a record that had stood since 1938, when which Yorkshire batsman had scored 364 for England against Australia in just his sixth test? This batsman took over from another Englishman, Wally Hammond, as holder of the record.
The name of which large town in southern England follows 'Rachael' in the name of the prominent pro-Corbyn Twitter account run by Rachael Cousins?

What adjective is used in astrophysics to refer to an extremely-dense type of 'matter', found in white dwarfs and other late-stage stars, whose behaviour is governed largely by quantum mechanics? The noun form of this adjective names a type of 'pressure' that prevents such stars from collapsing.
The story of Samson and Delilah is told in which book of the Old Testament?

What name was given to a public square used mainly as a market place in ancient Roman cities? The one of these in Rome contains the House of the Vestal Virgins, and the name for this area is used nowadays for any meeting place including virtual ones used for discussion on the internet.
Which character is Abominable in the title of a 1971 British horror film? He would Rise Again in its 1972 sequel, and was played by Vincent Price.
Hampton is the budget chain for which hotel brand? Zsa Zsa Gabor was married to the founder of this chain, one of whose sons married Elizabeth Taylor.
Formula One's Australian Grand Prix is held at the Albert Park circuit in which city?

The Belle Stars' first top 40 hit was a cover of a song originally recorded in 1965 by the Dixie Cups, although its success was limited by a cover version at the same time by Scottish singer Natasha. Which track was this?

Which Swiss linguist, semiotician and philosopher is regarded as one of the founders of 20th-century linguistics, and with Charles Sanders Peirce, one of the founders of semiotics? Course in General Linguistics was compiled from this thinker's lecture notes.
What three-word name is often given to the flower Strelitzia when used in floristry? The name refers to the flower's resemblance to an exotic creature.

Sport climbing at the 2024 Paris Olympics will award medals in speed climbing, and combined, which consists of bouldering and which other climbing discipline? In competitions, this event sees climbers have a few minutes to assess the wall before attempting a high, complex route during which they are protected from falls by rope and a belayer.

Which Scottish indie-rock band whose lead songwriter is Alex Kapranos won the NME Album of the Year award for their self-titled debut album in 2004? The album included the hits The Dark Side of the Matinée and Darts of Pleasure.
What name is shared by the state capital of Nebraska and a city in eastern England?

The namesake 'constant' of which English scientist is equal to the total charge of one mole of electrons? This scientist is also the inventor of a namesake 'cage' used to protect objects from electromagnetic radiation.

Which novel by Olga Tokarczuk, first published in Polish and translated into English by Jennifer Croft, won the International Booker Prize in 2018? It is a "philosophical rumination on modern-day travel" narrated by an un-named traveller.

Russian forces have been assisted in fighting around Bakhmut and Soledar by members of which paramilitary organisation, sometimes regarded as the de facto private army of Vladimir Putin? It is estimated they have lost 1,000 of their forces in recent months, with perhaps 900 being recruited convicts.
Asif Kapadia's Senna forms a trilogy of archive constructed documentaries alongside Amy and a 2019 film about which legendary Argentinian footballer, who died in 2020?

Which radio DJ hosts the Drivetime show on Greatest Hits radio, having previously hosted BBC Radio 2's show in that timeslot from 2010–18? Between 2001 and 2022, he hosted a film review programme on BBC Radio Five Live with Mark Kermode.

The Labour Party chose not to publicise Lord Boothby's relationship with Ronnie Kray due to Kray's involvement with which Labour MP? This MP had previously been a member of the Communist Party and wrote the William Hickey gossip column in The Daily Express.
Which first person shooter game series, released by Valve, follows a group of four 'Survivors' during a pandemic who must make their way to safehouses whilst avoiding the Zombie-like 'Infected'?

Pensées is a collection of philosophical fragments written by which 17th-century French polymath, who made many notable advances in mathematics and the sciences as well as philosophy? The book sets out this man's namesake 'wager' about belief in God.
The Roman naturalist and philosopher Pliny the Elder died in which natural disaster of 79 AD?

What is the term used to describe the phenomenon where a spinning object moving through a fluid (such as air) curves away from its principal flight path because of differences in pressure on either side of the object?

Described by Brian Eno as "perhaps the greatest drummer who has ever lived", which Nigerian musician is regarded as one of the founders of Afrobeat along with Fela Kuti? He is perhaps best known for his work in Kuti's band Africa 70.
Which country, part of the former Yugoslavia, is known in its native language as Crna Gora?

Lucas Pope is the only developer to win the Grand Prize at the Independent Game Festival on two occasions. His first win came for Papers, Please in 2013, his second was for which 2018 detective video game where the player takes the role of an insurance inspector on the titular boat?

In a January 2023 diss track, Shakira claimed her ex, Gerard Pique, had "swapped a Ferrari for a Twingo" – a small hatchback made by which French car company? Its most popular models include the Clio and Megane.

Jonathan, thought to be the oldest-known land animal, is what kind of reptile? This slow-moving animal was born in 1832 and has lived on the island of St Helena since 1882. A one-word answer is sufficient.
Who served as head of the Stasi, the East German secret police, from 1957–89?
Into which body of water do Europe's first and third longest rivers, the Volga and Ural, both flow?
Niall Horan was the sole Irish member of which successful boy band, whose number one singles include What Makes You Beautiful and Little Things?

British actor Mia Threapleton played a troubled teenager in 2023's BAFTA-winning drama I Am Ruth. Who co-starred as Threapleton's mother – perhaps an undemanding role, as she is Threapleton's mother in real life?

The Brazilian footballers Romario, Ronaldo and Rivaldo all won the FIFA World Player of the Year Award in the 1990s while playing for which European club? This team has been European champions on five occasions, though none of those wins involved these players.

Oliver Kilbourn was the leader of an art group named after which Northumberland town? Its members were mainly employed by the nearby Woodhorn and Ellington collieries leading to this group's alternative name of the Pitmen Painters.
Who directed the 1998 film Belly, starring Nas and DMX? He is known primarily for music videos for rap artists that featured a fisheye lens including Missy Elliott's The Rain.
Tasha Stones is the first British Sign Language contestant on what Channel 4 show? She is appearing in the current season, which saw Alison Hammond replace Matt Lucas as co-host.
Disgrace by J. M. Coetzee is primarily set in which Commonwealth country? Other Booker Prize-winning novels set here include The Conservationist, and The Promise.
At which 1683 battle did the combined forces of the Holy League and Poland-Lithuania lift the Ottoman siege of a major city and halt the Ottoman expansion into Central Europe?

The fourth asteroid to be discovered, after Ceres, Pallas and Juno, what is the second largest asteroid by mass and volume after Ceres? Visited by the spacecraft Dawn in 2011, it is also the brightest asteroid visible from earth.
Daft Punk's Thomas Bangalter joined forces with Alan Braxe and vocalist Benjamin Diamond to form what French house trio, who reached UK number two in 1998 with Music Sounds Better With You?

What rhetorical technique – partly named for an American creationist – sees a debater attempt to overwhelm their opponent by providing an excessive number of arguments with no regard for the accuracy or strength of those arguments?
Which tennis grip requires the knuckle of the index finger to be placed on bevel 5 of the racket? This grip generates extreme top spin on forehands but is not recommended for casual players.

Which carbonated citrus fruit drink was developed in Algeria in 1933 and is particularly popular in the Francophone world? In 2008, a UK advert for this brand featuring sexually suggestive animals had to be shown after 9pm.
Which chemical element takes its name from the German city in which the GSI Helmholtz Centre, where it was first synthesised in 1994, is located?
When Tony Gallagher joined The Times as Deputy Editor in 2020, who succeeded him as editor of The Sun, a position this person still holds?
Which London park is home to Speakers' Corner and the Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Fountain?

The 'Second Viennese Trio' consists of the serialist composers Arnold Schoenberg, Alban Berg, and which other Austrian composer and conductor who is best known for works such as Passacaglia and Concerto for Nine Instruments?

Which hat, also known as the Uzbek hat and Jinnah cap, was developed in Bukhara and made from the wool of a particular breed of fat-tailed sheep? It is associated with the political leaders Muhammad Ali Jinnah and Hamed Karzai.
In which motorsport do two cars race in a straight line from a standing start over a quarter of a mile? In the United States, this sport is governed by the National Hot Rod Association.
In the second book of the Lord of the Rings trilogy, The Two Towers, what is the name of the giant spider living in Cirith Ungol that Frodo and Sam are led to by Gollum?
Which American actor played Detective Bobby Simone in seasons two to six of NYPD Blue? He went on to play Matt Santos in the final two seasons of The West Wing, and Nero Padilla in Sons of Anarchy.
American actor Margaret Qualley starred in the titular role in the Netflix drama Maid. Who played Qualley's mother –perhaps and undemanding role since she is Qualley's mother in real life?

The Dutch footballers Marco van Basten, Ruud Gullit and Frank Rijkaard were the top three in the vote for the Ballon d'Or Award of 1988, during their time at which club? The trio were part of two of the team's seven European Cup wins, with all three scoring goals in a final.

Joseph R. Bagshawe was the leader of an art group named after which North Yorkshire coastal village? Laura Knight was involved in this group as well as her involvement in the Newlyn School, and both groups laid stress on plein air painting using natural light.
Who directed the 2010 film Never Let Me Go? He is known for his music videos including Scream by Michael and Janet Jackson, and Hurt by Johnny Cash.

Wisdom, thought to be the oldest-known wild bird, is what kind of bird? First banded on Midway Atoll in 1956, she is a Laysan species of this bird, which is rather smaller than its wandering species, which has the largest wingspan of any bird. A one-word answer is sufficient.
Who was the last Communist leader of East Germany? He served for six weeks following Erich Honecker's removal from that position.
Into which body of water do Europe's second and fourth longest rivers, the Danube and Dnieper, both flow?
Nadine Coyle was the sole Irish member of which successful girl group, whose number one singles include Sound of the Underground and The Promise?

Tony Allen played the drums on which Nigerian musician's album Aura? This jùjú singer founded his band African Beats in 1967 and went on to become one of the first African pop musicians to gain international recognition. His best-known albums include Juju Music and Synchro System.
Which country, part of the former USSR, is known in its native language as Sakartvelo?

Another winner of the Grand Prize at the Independent Game Festival is which 2015 action-adventure game in which a player is explores a solar system that is stuck in a 22-minute time loop before its star goes supernova?

Shakira's Gerard Pique diss track also sees her claim he'd "swapped a Rolex for" what other make of watch? In addition to its G-Shock range of sports watches, this Japanese firm is also known for its electronic keyboards and calculators.

Which UK digital radio station began in 2019 with a show presented by Simon Mayo? The station's presenters include other ex-Radio 2 stalwarts Richard Allinson and Charles Nove, and it takes its name from an opera house.

Monadology is a short work on metaphysics by which 17th- and 18th-century German polymath, who made many notable advances in mathematics and the sciences as well as philosophy? Voltaire satirised this man' belief that we live in the "best of all possible worlds", a remark made in his earlier work Theodicy.
The 79 AD eruption of Vesuvius buried which ancient city under ash, preserving a snapshot of Roman life? Along with nearby Herculaneum this city forms a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

What is the term used to describe the tendency of a fluid jet to stay attached to a convex surface, causing it to curve around that surface, as observed in certain aerodynamic and fluid dynamics scenarios?
In medicine, what ten-letter word is used to describe an adverse effect suffered by a patient due to diagnostic or therapeutic processes performed by a doctor?
What is the capital of the US state which shares its abbreviation with that for the chemical element Argon?

Which US quizzer holds the record for longest winning streak on Jeopardy!, at 74 shows, and in early 2020 won the Greatest of All Time show against Brad Rutter and James Holzhauer, taking his TV gameshow winnings to over $5m?

Paul Young sung the first line on the original version of Do They Know It's Christmas. Which singer whose seven UK number ones include Spinning Around and Can't Get You Out of My Head sung the first line on the 1989 version of the song?
Appearing on Granta's list of Young British Novelists in 1983, which Nigerian-born British novelist is the author of The Bride Price, Second Class Citizen, and The Joys of Motherhood?
Which Arsenal centre-forward has been top scorer in the FA Women's Super League for the last two seasons? She is also the all-time leading goal scorer for the Netherlands national team.
The name of what flower is given to the Revolution of 2005 in Kyrgyzstan that led to President Askar Akayev falling from power?
Betteshanger and Tilmanstone, both closed in the late 1980s, were collieries located in which southern English county, not generally associated with coal mining?

Which middle eastern lake is, with its shore at 430 metres below sea level, Earth's lowest elevation on land? It is over 9 times as salty as the ocean which means that swimming in it is akin to floating.
To prevent Germany taking control of its ships, at which Mediterranean port city did Vichy France scuttle its main fleet in 1942?
What word, from a Czech word meaning "small hook", describes the diacritical mark shaped like a small letter V that can be found above the letters C, S, and Z in many Slavic languages?

In 1916, which German physicist provided the first exact solution to Einstein field equations? His solution describes a gravitational field outside a spherical, nonrotating mass and is useful for calculating gravitational time dilation.
Cranham, the village in Gloucestershire, gives its name to a tune written by Gustav Holst as the setting for a poem by Christina Rossetti. That setting is well known as which Christmas carol?
Under what name did Matilda Powles (1864-1952) become a famous music hall performer? Her stage persona involved male impersonation and this character was a typical dandy or fop of the era.
Which cooperative card game, winner of the Spiel Des Jahres in 2013, has a name which means 'fireworks' in Japanese?
What first name links the title character in Virginia Woolf's Mrs Dalloway and a very long novel by Samuel Richardson?
I Am Trying to Break Your Heart, War on War, and Jesus, Etc., are all tracks on which acclaimed 2002 album?
Doing so with The Ballad of Narayama and The Eel, who is the only Japanese director to win two Palmes d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival? The answer is not Akira Kurosawa.
Which English golfer was the first non-American player to top the LPGA money list, doing so in 1994, and played a record 11 Solheim Cups from 1990 until 2011?

Answer: On the City of God against the Pagans

Which Finn won the 1998 and 1999 Formula One drivers' championships while driving for McLaren?

Abolished in English law in 1967, what term beginning with B was the offence committed by people who are overly officious in instigating prosecution of groundless litigation, or who bring repeated acts of litigation for the purposes of profit or harassment? It is similar to the modern concept of vexatious litigation.
Very few American companies have a single letter stock symbol on the New York Stock Exchange. Which of the US big four financial services institutions has the symbol C?

Despite being unable to read music, which jazz pianist wrote the standard Misty, which became a hit for Johnny Mathis? His 1955 album Concert by the Sea sold over a million copies by 1958.

Appearing on Granta's list of Young British Novelists in 2013, which British-American author coined the word "Afropolitanism" and drew on her own family's experience as part of the West African diaspora for her novel Ghana Must Go?
Which Canadian centre-forward is the all-time record goal scorer in women's international football? She was also the leading goal scorer at the 2012 London Olympics.
The name of what flower is given to the Revolution of 2003 in Georgia that led to President Eduard Shevardnadze falling from power?

In which wooded area in western England is there a small coalfield which was regulated by a system called freemining, where individuals were granted leases to mine specific areas? Because of this, it was not nationalised along with the rest of the British coal industry in 1946.

What is that capital of the US state which shares its abbreviation with that of the chemical element Calcium?

Answer: Burlington Bertie (accept ...From Bow, although it was actually a different song)

What first name links the title character in Flaubert's Madame Bovary with a Jane Austen protagonist?

What word, from a Polish word for "little tail", describes the diacritical mark shaped like a small hook that can be found beneath vowels in several European languages?

What is the three-letter name of the brand of calorie-free cola introduced by Pepsi in 1993? In recent years it has been positioned as a rival to Coke Zero and, like its rival, marketed more at young men than young women.

Doing so with Torment and Miss Julie, who is the only Swedish director to win two Palmes d'Or (then referred to as the Grand Prix du Festival) at the Cannes Film Festival? The answer is not Ingmar Bergman.

What is the title of the work by Boethius written in around 523AD in which the author considers predestination, free will and other religious questions without reference to Christianity?

Broadcast since 2017, which Irish sitcom stars Alex Murphy and Chris Walley as teenage criminals growing up in Cork?

Which Spaniard won the 2005 and 2006 Formula One drivers' championships while driving for Renault?

Abolished in English law in 1967, what term beginning with C was the crime committed by a person who maintained, or financed, another person in a lawsuit on condition that the subject matter of the action is to be shared with the first person? It is similar to the modern concept of litigation finance.

Travis Knight, the son of Nike founder Phil, is the CEO of which stop-motion animation studio named after a famous real-life canine? Coraline was made by this studio.

Who are the only all-female group to have won the Country Music Association Entertainer of the Year award? They are perhaps best known for their vocal opposition to George Bush and the invasion of Iraq.
Which actor plays the male lead in the Alfred Hitchcock films The Man Who Knew Too Much and Rear Window?
Which sea battle of 31BC saw Octavian's fleet win a decisive victory over the fleet of Mark Anthony and Cleopatra, thereby consolidating Roman power?
Which American writer's works include the 1991 epistolary novel I Love Dick and the 2017 biography After Kathy Acker?

From the Latin for "little foot", in botany what seven-letter word is given to the stalk that attaches the leaf blade to the stem?

What activity particularly associated with a certain European country might be practiced in an arena known as the corrida?

Which Brazilian striker moved to AC Milan in 1958 and played for the Italian national side too? His 14 goals in the 1962-3 European Cup for Milan was unbeaten until Cristiano Ronaldo managed 17 in 2013-4.

Organising the chemical elements by an idealised orbital filling instead of valence, which French engineer developed the left-step periodic table, an alternative way of depicting the elements, in 1928?

What activity has Liverpudlian Mark Roberts performed over 500 times since 1993, including at the Super Bowl, the Miss World Contest, the World Snooker Championships, Crufts, and on the floating weather map on the TV show This Morning?

Running from 1983 to 1993, and presented by, among others, Alan Parry and Tony Gubba, which BBC1 entertainment show required canoers and kayakers to navigate white water rafting and obstacle courses, in the shortest possible time?

Diogenes was a leading thinker in which ancient school of philosophy, the name of which is nowadays used more widely to describe a particular state of mind?

Which British political party split from the Liberal Party in 1886 and merged with the Conservatives in 1912? They governed in coalition with the Conservatives from 1895 to 1905. Your answer requires two specific words.

Jade Jones has won two Olympic gold medals in which martial art?

What word describes the pastime which involves people dressing up to recreate events from history, especially battles? The members of the society The Sealed Knot participate in this pastime.

Megan Ellison, the daughter of Oracle founder Larry, is the CEO of which film production company, named after one of the Himalayan eight-thousanders? In 2019 it co-produced Missing Link with Travis Knight's Laika.
To which character in Don Giovanni, a woman abandoned by the title character, does Leporello sing the Catalogue Aria? As a result of its revelations, she vows revenge upon Don Giovanni.

What name is given to a ledge, sometimes called a mercy seat, formed on the underside of a folding seat in a church? When the seat is folded up, the ledge is intended to support someone standing in prayer.

What 1638 agreement was signed by thousands of Scots opposed to having to accept a prayer book introduced by Charles I? Its name features a word for a legal document or agreement, and is the only word you need for the points. Its supporters were known by that word with the letters "-ers" on the end.
What nine-letter adjective beginning with "R" describes an allele whose effect is overridden by another, dominant, allele? Such alleles are, by convention, represented by lower case letters.
Unusually, the Major League Baseball team the Twins has a state not a city in its name. Which state?
The ICC team of the tournament in the 2019 Cricket World Cup for men included (as twelfth man) which New Zealand fast-medium bowler whose first name is Trent?
A leaf that lacks a petiole, and hence attaches directly to the stem, can be described by what seven-letter adjective? It features in the name of a species of oak tree.
Which South African dish with its origins in the local Malay community consists of spiced minced meat, often beef or lamb, with an egg-based topping?

Which eight-letter term for a bullfighter is still popular in the UK, popularised by Bizet's Carmen, but little used nowadays in Spain, although may sometimes be used to describe a bullfighter on horseback?

Who is the only six-time winner of the Country Music Association Entertainer of the Year? He has sold more albums in the US than any other solo artist, with albums including No Fences, Ropin' The Wind and In Pieces.
Which actor plays the male lead in the Alfred Hitchcock films Notorious and North by Northwest?
Which sea battle of 480BC saw the Greek fleet led by Themistocles win a decisive victory over the Persian fleet of Xerxes, bring an end to Persian threats to capture the Greek mainland?
Which British writer's works include the 2016 non-fiction work The Lonely City and the 2018 novel Crudo?
The chart acts Herb Alpert, Al Martino, and Mink De Ville have all had hit singles with titles that mention which European nationality?
Phineas Barnum teamed up with which other circus impresario to form their doubly eponymous circus in 1881, which after Barnum's death became known as The Greatest Show On Earth?

Depicting the rescue of the titular boy, Watson and the Shark is perhaps the masterpiece of which Anglo-American artist of the 18th-19th centuries?

Which Argentinian striker moved to Internazionale in 1957, and played for the Italian national side too? His 33 goals in Serie A for Inter in 1958-9 was unbeaten until Gonzalo Higuain scored 36 in 2015-6.

Depicting the chemical elements in a spiral with two bulges representing the transition metals and actinides/lanthanides, which German born chemist developed the two-dimensional spiral, an alternative way of depicting the elements, in 1964?
Snooker player Alain Robidoux [ROBBIE-doo], serial killer Paul Bernardo and Nobel Prize winning physicist Donna Strickland were all born in which country?
Which port just south of Dublin was known as Kingstown between 1821 and 1920? This was the major seaport for ferries from the UK until the early 21st century, with services finally ceasing in 2015.
Zeno of Citium was the founder of which Ancient school of philosophy, the name of which is nowadays used more widely to describe a particular state of mind?

Which British political party split from the Liberal Party in 1931 and merged with the Conservatives in 1968? At the 1951 General Election they received over a million votes and had 21 MPs elected. Your answer requires two specific words.
In mathematics, which Greek letter (in both upper and lower case forms) denotes difference, and more generally the degree of change in a given variable?
Neil Adams has won two Olympic silver medals in which martial art?

Which sea lies between Vancouver Island, mainland British Columbia and Washington State? It includes the Strait of Georgia, the Strait of Juan de Fuca, and Puget Sound, and takes its name from an indigenous group native to the area.
During what live televised event did Robert Opel streak in 1974, prompting the host David Niven to joke about him "stripping off and showing his shortcomings"?

Running from 1979 to 1988, and presented by, among others, Dave Lee Travis and Peter Purves, which BBC1 entertainment show required motorcyclists to navigate hazardous tracks with obstacles in the shortest possible time?

Je t'aime was not the first UK number one on Major Minor records. That had come in 1968 with which record with a reduplicated title, the subject of a more rock-oriented cover by Billy Idol in 1981, which also reached the top ten?
Which mountains in New South Wales – part of the great dividing range – get their name from the colourful haze caused by Eucalyptus trees?

Answer: Brazen bull (accept bronze bull, brass bull or Sicilian bull)
Question: According to Diodorus Siculus, what ancient torture device was allegedly invented by an Athenian named Perilaus? Effectively a primitive oven, victims would be forced inside the device and a fire would be lit beneath it, roasting the victims to death.

Which French physicist is best known for an experiment he conducted in 1851, in which a pendulum was suspended from the dome of the Panthéon in Paris and used to demonstrate the rotation of the Earth?

In 1908, Japanese chemist Kikunae Ikeda identified which fifth basic taste group, to add to sour, salty, sweet and bitter? Soy sauce and meat extracts are among foods which display this taste, whose name translates from Japanese as "pleasant savoury taste".

The Rocket Richard [ree·SHARD] Trophy is awarded in the NHL to the player who scores the most goals each league season. Which Russian player has won the trophy nine times, all of which came while playing with the Washington Capitals?

Also known as a holoalphabetic sentence, what name is given to a sentence with contains every letter of the alphabet at least once? "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog" is the most famous example.
Which South African-born Australian film editor is best known for her collaborations with her husband George Miller? She won an Academy Award and BAFTA for editing Mad Max: Fury Road.
Which year of the 20th century completes the name of the W. B. Yeats poem in which he tells how "a terrible beauty is born": Easter [ ]?
Heldentenor, meaning "heroic tenor", refers to a powerful, dramatic tenor voice. Which composer created the Heldentenor roles Siegfried and Tristan?
