Answer: Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle or Treaty of Aachen
Question: Which peace treaty ended the War of the Austrian Succession? It was signed in a city that was then a Free Imperial City in the Holy Roman Empire and is now in Germany very close to the Dutch and Belgian borders.

Named after the river that flows into it, what is the name of the large freshwater lake in the Netherlands which was created by the construction of the Afsluitdijk [AFF·shlow·dyke] embankment in the late 1920s? The embankment cut off the old salt water bay of Zuiderzee [zow·der·ZAY] from the North Sea.

Which Italian-based fashion house, whose French founder died in 2019, was infamous for a collection co-designed by Lindsay Lohan that had a disastrous reception at Paris fashion week in 2009, when it featured models wearing sequinned, heart-shaped nipple tassels?
With a length of about 2.3 metres, Dall's is the largest species of which mammal from the family Phocoenidae?
The blockchain predominantly uses a system abbreviated to PoW, relying on miners to commit their computing power to the network in exchange for rewards. For what does PoW stand in this context?
Santa Clara, Belenenses and Boavista are challengers to the "big three" in which European country's top football division?
The Boss Original highlighter pen is manufactured by which German stationer, also known for their fineliners and pencils?
All electron shells contain which subshell, which can hold at most 2 electrons? Your answer should be a single letter.

What is the two word name, taken from ancient Greek, of the figure of speech in which the normal order of two sentences, clauses, etc, is reversed? 'Bred and born' or 'putting on one's shoes and socks' are examples.

Which 1987 graphic adventure video game developed by Lucasfilm centres on the attempts of Dave Miller to rescue his girlfriend from the titular home of a mad scientist? It was the first Lucasfilm game to use the game engine SCUMM, and a sequel, Day of the Tentacle, was released in 1993.
In Greek mythology, which King of Ephyra was punished by being forced to roll an immense boulder up a hill only for it to roll down every time it neared the top, repeating this action for eternity?

Characters very rarely stay dead for long in superhero comics. One notable exception is Ben Parker, who died in the same issue as his first appearance, Amazing Fantasy #15, inspiring his nephew Peter to use his great power responsibly and become which superhero?
Who was the oldest person to accede to the British throne? This monarch ruled from 1830 to '37 before being succeeded by his niece Queen Victoria. Name and regnal number is needed.
What is the unit of currency in Lesotho? Its name is the Sesotho word for "mountain", and its plural form is the name of a subrange of the Drakensberg.
Which female swimmer became Canada's most successful Olympian of all time after winning three medals at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics?
Which word links a station on the London Underground Northern Line, the official report into a Presidential assassination and the first name of the businessman nicknamed the "Sage of Omaha"?

Which actress, known for her collaborations with Keith Lemon, played Charlotte Hinchcliffe in The Inbetweeners? She was runner up on I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here in 2018, where her rivals included Chaser Anne Hegerty.
Writing in Le Charivari, which French art critic coined the term "impressionism" for the 19th-century art movement? He had intended the term to be taken satirically.

Which Grade II* [two star]-listed bridge over the Thames, which connects its namesake district of west London with Barnes, has been closed indefinitely to road traffic since 2019 because of weaknesses in its structure? For a year in 2020-21 it was even closed to pedestrians and cyclists.

Which Conservative MP for Wealden alleged in January 2022 that Conservative whip Mark Spencer had told her that she was removed as a junior minister in a 2020 reshuffle because her "Muslimness" was perceived as a problematic issue?

In materials science, stress is the physical quantity which represents the forces that particles exert on one another. What name is given to the measure of deformation of the material causes by stress? An important curve illustrates the relationship between the two for a given material.
Which disease, a form of bacterial pneumonia often spread by air conditioning systems, was first identified in 1976 at a Philadelphia convention for army veterans, from which it takes its name?

Which Italian fashion house is renowned for its multicolour intricate zigzag knitted garments and was founded in 1953 by a former hurdler, who competed in the 1948 Summer Olympic Games, and his wife, who came from a family of shawlmakers?
With a length of about 1.4 metres, what is the smallest species of porpoise and the smallest of all living cetaceans?

A more environmentally friendly alternative to the proof of work blockchain is PoS, where instead of computational power, validators are selected on the basis of the quantity of blockchain tokens they have. For what does the S stand in this context?
Heracles Almelo, Vitesse and AZ are challengers to the "big three" in which European country's top football division?
Spinto soprano, meaning "pushed soprano", refers to a rich, dramatic soprano voice. Which composer created the spinto roles Tosca and Manon?
Which rock supergroup was formed in 2002, when former members of Guns 'n' Roses – including Slash and Duff McKagan – joined Scott Weiland, originally of Stone Temple Pilots?
Which peace treaty ended the War of 1812 between the United States and the United Kingdom? It was signed in a city that was then in the United Netherlands but now the third largest city in Belgium.

Nearly all of which province of the Netherlands, with its capital at Lelystad, was created in the 1950s and 1960s by draining southern parts of the IJsselmeer to create artificial polders? Almere is another city in this smallest Dutch province.

The Vezina Trophy is awarded in the NHL to the goaltender voted the league's best each season. Which Czech player has won the most trophies since voting criteria was changed in 1981, winning all six of the awards with the Buffalo Sabres?

A pangram might be seen as the opposite of what word beginning with L, a piece of writing in which a letter or letters is deliberately avoided? Georges Perec's novel La Disparition, which omits the letter E, is the most famous example.

Which British costume designer won an Academy Award and a BAFTA for her work on Mad Max: Fury Road? She is also known for her work on Merchant Ivory films including A Room with a View and Howards End.
Which year of the 20th century completes the name of the W. H. Auden poem in which he speaks of a "low, dishonest decade": September 1, [ ]?
Another range called the Blue Mountains, famous for coffee production, is found in Surrey and Middlesex Counties of which Caribbean island nation?

What method of ritual execution was ostensibly used by the Norse, although is only detailed in works of skaldic poetry? In it, the victim's ribs would be severed from their spine and their lungs pulled through the opening, creating a pair of "wings".

What name, after the French physicist who described in 1835, is given to an apparent force that acts on moving objects within a rotating frame of reference? It is usually discussed in the context of the Earth's rotation, and is often wrongly cited as an explanation for the direction in which draining water spins.

Which chemical compound was identified by Kikunae Ikeda as one of the key ingredients which created an umami taste? "Chinese Restaurant Syndrome" is the name given to alleged feelings of discomfort caused by ingesting this compound, although the medical evidence for the condition's existence is disputed.
Hammersmith Bridge was designed by which civil engineer who is best remembered for creating London's sewerage system in the years following the 1858 Great Stink?

Which Conservative MP for Hazel Grove, a vice-chairman of the 1922 Committee, alleged in January 2022 that Conservative whips had used tactics amounting to blackmail in an attempt to force backbench MPs to support Boris Johnson as Prime Minister?
The highest point on a stress-strain curve defines what type of strength, defined as how much a material can withstand being pulled before breaking?

Which disease, spread by tick bites and which may cause fever, joint pains and have long-term effects, was first recognised as a new condition in 1975 in the Connecticut town from which it takes its name?
Which female swimmer became Australia's most successful Olympian of all time after winning seven medals at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics?
Which word links a station on the London Underground Piccadilly Line, a high-end UK shoe retailer founded in 1873 and the surname of a UK pacifist philosopher imprisoned for six months in 1918?

Which singer and actress is the mother of Emily Atack? She provided voices for Spitting Image and Eurotrash, wrote the original theme to Surprise Surprise, and had a UK number 2 hit with More Than In Love.
Which French art critic created the term "fauves" for a group of post-Impressionists who exhibited with Henri Matisse? He had intended the term to be pejorative.

In Greek mythology, which father of Niobe was made to stand in a pool of water beneath a fruit tree with low branches, with the fruit ever eluding his grasp, and the water always receding before he could take a drink?

Characters very rarely stay dead for long in superhero comics. Notable exceptions are Martha and Thomas Wayne, who died in Detective Comics #33, the same issue as they first appeared, traumatising their son Bruce into becoming which superhero?
Who was the second oldest person to accede to the British throne? This monarch ruled from 1901 to '10 after the death of his mother Queen Victoria. Name and regnal number is needed.
The name is also the site of the first major victory in the Eritrean War of Independence: what is the unit of currency in Eritrea?
Which German stationer is Europe's largest manufacturer of pencils and pencil erasers? Their distinctive black and yellow pencils are widely used in schools.
Although widespread in continental Europe, the British population of which species of bunting is restricted to around 1,000 pairs found almost exclusively in coastal farmland in south Devon?
What forename is shared by two of Christ's apostles; one often referred to as "The Zealot" and another also known as St Peter?
The Ford Transit and Ford Transit Custom are Britain's two best-selling models of van. Which manufacturer makes the Sprinter, which came in third?
What was the surname of Michael, the Irish jockey who rode Commander in Chief, Galileo and Sea the Stars to Epsom Derby wins?
With an American city in the title, which TV medical drama originally ran from 1994 to 2000? It starred Adam Arkin, Hector Elizondo and Mandy Patinkin.

Which British philosopher and author of The Concept of Mind coined the term "thick description" in a 1949 essay to describe writing which includes not just surface-level descriptions of behaviour, but also looks at the context of such behaviour, e.g. its motivation and effect on others?
Former Court of Appeal judge Janet Smith led the enquiry, which ran from 2000 to 2002, into which British GP and serial killer, concluding that he had killed well over 200 people?
In March 2020, Andrew Bailey replaced which man as Governor of the Bank of England?
What name is given to the steep cliff on the Capitoline Hill that overlooks the Roman Forum and was used as a place of execution during the Republic?

There are numerous theories about who originated the US conspiracy theory QANON. One theory claims it was originated by which group of Italian authors, four of whom wrote the novel Q under the pen name Luther Blissett? Their name means "anonymous" in Chinese.

Answer: Tales of a Fourth Grade Nothing
Question: Which Judy Blume novel first published in 1972 centres on the 9 year old Peter Hatcher and his frustrations with his annoying 2.5-year-old brother, who is loud, mischievous and demanding?
The last element discovered in nature was which element, with atomic number 87, discovered in 1939 by Marguerite Perey and named after her home nation?
Known as Eggman in Japan, what is the surname of the mad scientist with forename Ivo who is the main antagonist of Sonic the Hedgehog?
Sponge biscuits known as ladyfingers form the basis of which Italian dessert in which they are dipped in coffee and covered with a mixture of eggs, sugar and mascarpone cheese?
Cowley, Jericho, Barton and Iffley are suburbs of which city, around 56 miles from London?
Federico Fellini won a Best Foreign Film Academy Award for which 1973 comedy drama about an adolescent boy named Titta growing up in a village near Rimini in Fascist Italy?
Born in 1975, which Chilean is the only male tennis player in history to have been World Number One but never won a Grand Slam singles title?
What name is given to the type of women's shoe, often flat but sometimes heeled, where there is no support around the back of the ankle?
Remains of a species of ancient human standing about 1.1 metres tall were found in 2003 on the island of Flores, part of the Lesser Sunda islands in which large Asian island republic?

Future Oscar-winner Jennifer Hudson finished seventh in the third season of American Idol. The series was won by which R&B singer who beat Diana DeGarmo in the final and went on to have hits with I Believe and When I See U?
Three of Five Nations, the Native American tribes which together composed the Iroquois League, were Mohawk, Seneca and Oneida. Name either of the other two.
The cricket podcast Tailenders is a collaboration between Radio 1's Greg James, Felix White of The Maccabees and which still-active cricketer, himself a tail end batsman?
Among the most famous works of the American painter Anna Elizabeth Klumpke was her 1889 portrait of which leading figure in women's rights, the lead author of the 1848 Declaration of Sentiments?
What name is given to a small service lift typically used to transport food and related items between a kitchen and other floors in the same building?
Which hip-hop/R&B singer had a major hit with the track Doo Wop (That Thing) from her debut solo album The Miseducation of..., and won the Grammy Award for Best New Artist in 1999?
Which Rococo palace in Vienna served as the main summer residence of the Habsburg dynasty? The imperial menagerie within its grounds still exists in the form of Vienna zoo.
What eight letter word which can be made from the letters of the phrase PRESIDENT'S CUP means "a position requiring little or no work but giving the holder status or financial benefit"?
Breitenfield, Lutzen and White Mountain were battles in which war fought over much of Europe between 1618 and 1648?

Hippolyte Fizeau and Albert Michelson both give their names to configurations of which type of lab equipment which splits a light beam into parts and then recombines them to produce its namesake pattern?
What adjective precedes Russian in the nickname of Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 2?

In quilting, what two-word name for a type of building is given to a block where there are rectangular strips of fabric around a central square, typically dark on one side and light on the other? In folklore, these blocks were said to indicate a safe house on the Underground Railroad.

Which British boxer won the 2017-18 World Boxing Super Series super-middleweight tournament? In doing so he won the WBA World super-middleweight title, which he held until his defeat to Canelo Álvarez in December 2020.
With an American city in the title, which TV series, centred on a law practice, ran from 2004 to 2008 and starred James Spader, William Shatner and Candice Bergen?

Which American anthropologist became particularly associated with Ryle's concept of "thick description", employing it in essays such as Deep Play: Notes on the Balinese Cockfight, in which he deployed it to analyse the title activity?

Former Court of Appeal Judge Janet Smith led the review, which ran from 2012 to 2016, into the BBC's links with which disgraced DJ, presenter and charity fundraiser, finding he had carried out at least 80 sexual assaults on BBC premises on which he had worked?
In September 2020, Tim Davie replaced which man as Director General of the BBC?

Although widespread in continental Europe, the British population of which species of bunting is restricted to around 1,500 pairs found almost exclusively in the Caledonian forests of the Moray basin the northern end of the Great Glen?
What forename is shared by two of Christ's apostles; one a son of Alphaeus often referred to as "The Less" and the other the brother of John who is the patron saint of Spain?
The fourth best-selling model of van behind the Transits and the Sprinter was which manufacturer's Vivaro?
What was the surname of Johnny, the Irish jockey who rode Sinndar, High Chaparral and Motivator to Epsom Derby wins?
With the punning full name of Miles Prower, what is the nickname of the fox who is Sonic the Hedgehog's sidekick? It refers to a bodily feature of which he has two rather than the usual one.
Ladies' fingers is a common name given to which flowering plant of the mallow family whose seed pods are often used as a thickener in gumbo soup and is called bhindi in Indian cuisine?
Clifton, Stoke Bishop, Fishponds and Hotwells are suburbs of which city, around 118 miles from London?
Federico Fellini won a Best Foreign Film Academy Award for which 1957 drama film about the titular Rome prostitute, played by Giulietta Masina, who searches in vain for true love?

Another execution site on the Capitoline Hill was the Gemonian Stairs, which saw the deaths of Sejanus and Vitellius. The head of which man, the last king of Dacia, was thrown down these stairs following his defeat to Trajan at the Battle of Sarmizegetusa?

There are numerous theories about who originated the US conspiracy theory QANON. One theory claims it was originated by which organisation, which on three occasions has posted sets of puzzles online in an effort to recruit codebreakers from the public?

In Tales of a Fourth Grade Nothing, what is the nickname of Peter Hatcher's annoying younger brother, whose real forename is Farley? This nickname features in the title of three further novels featuring the Hatcher family.

Francium is the second rarest element in nature with little more than 30 grams in total existing at any one time in the earth's crust. Which halogen with atomic number 85 whose name means "unstable" is rarest, with only one gram in the earth's crust at any one time?

Three of Five Civilized Tribes, an ethnocentric concept developed by early European Americans who considered certain Native American peoples to be more advanced than others, were the Cherokee, Seminole and Creek. Name either of the other two.

The rugby podcast The Good, The Bad and the Rugby is a collaboration between Alex Payne of Sky Sports, former England player James Haskell and which other former player who like Haskell has a famous wife?

Also among Anna Elizabeth Klumpke's most famous works was her 1898 portrait of which other artist? This painter of animals, including her monumental artwork The Horse Fair, began a relationship with Klumpke in later life.
What name is given to a passenger lift that moves in a slow, continuous loop around a building without stopping? Its name is said to refer to its similarity to a set of prayer beads.

Jelena Janković and Karolína Plíšková could equal this "achievement" if they fail to win a slam before they retire, but who is the only female tennis player to have retired from the game having been world number one but without having won a Grand Slam singles title? She is also part of the only brother-sister pair to have both achieved number 1 ranking.
What name is given to the type of women's shoe, which may be flat or heeled, where there is a single strap supporting the ankle?
Remains of a species of ancient human closely related to the Neanderthals were found in 2010 in the Denisova cave in the Altai mountains in which very large country?

Future Queen frontman Adam Lambert was the runner-up in the eighth season of American Idol. He lost in the final to which pop-rock singer who went on to have hits with No Boundaries and Live Like We're Dying?

Hippolyte Fizeau's experiments with interferometry were later used to support the theory of special relativity, but they initially appeared to support the partial aether drag hypothesis proposed by which scientist, whose namesake equations describe the behaviour of light passing through mediums with different indices of refraction?
What other nationality, not Russian, provides the nickname of Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 3?

In quilting, what two-word name containing the name of a bird is given to a block where four triangles emanate from the centre, each flanked by another triangle? In folklore, these blocks were said to indicate the direction of travel escaped slaves should take in relation to migrating birds.

Which British boxer won the WBO world super-middleweight title in 2019 and is due to fight Canelo Álvarez in May? A former WBO World Middleweight champion, he is also the first member of the travelling community to be a two-weight world champion.
Lauryn Hill's Grammy for Best New Artist came two years after she had won Grammys for the song Killing Me Softly and the album The Score, which she won as the lead singer of which band?
Which Baroque palace complex in Vienna was built as a summer residence for Prince Eugene of Savoy and now houses a museum which contains Gustav Klimt's The Kiss?
What eight letter word which can be made from the letters of the phrase PRESIDENT'S CUP means, in Australian cricket, "extras"?
Quiberon Bay, Plassey and Plains of Abraham were battles in which war fought over much of the world between 1756 and 1763?

Which racetrack near Chemnitz in the former East Germany replaced the Nürburgring in 1998 as the site of Germany's motorcycle Grand Prix? In 2021 Marc Marquez won at this track on the 11th consecutive occasion.
Which of the 'Seven Summits' is the highest point in South America, as well as being the highest point in the southern and western hemispheres?

Twenty Love Poems and a Song of Despair is a work by which Chilean poet-diplomat, who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1971? He is said to have taken his professional surname from that of a Czech poet whose forename was Jan [YAN].

Oyster and Imperial are variants of what style of beer? The former are sometimes brewed with the namesake shellfish, and the latter got its name through being exported to Saint Petersburg during the reign of Catherine the Great.
Which 1901 opera by Antonín Dvořák is based on the fairy tales of Karel Jaromír Erben and Božena Němcová? Elements of the plot are similar to The Little Mermaid and Undine.

One of several techniques for solving the phase problem in x-ray crystallography, what adjective does the I stand for in the technique MIR, if the M stands for multiple and the R for replacement? This technique involves soaking and crystallizing proteins in solutions containing different metal ions and comparing the diffraction patterns they generate.
What five-letter adjective precedes "party" in the expression used by then Tory Chairman Theresa May to describe her party at the 2002 Conservative Party conference?
Which 2010 film starring Angelina Jolie and Johnny Depp was a remake of the 2005 French film Anthony Zimmer?

Lydia West played Bethany in which 2019 Russell T. Davies drama series that shares its name with the music project led by Olly Alexander? This show also starred Emma Thompson as a populist politician who transforms Britain into a fascist state over the course of a decade.

Which vessel served as the Japanese flagship at the Battle of Tsushima in 1905? Now preserved as a museum ship in Yokosuka it is the only remaining example of a pre-dreadnought battleship anywhere in the world.

Which major shopping street in Nicosia links Turkish-controlled northern Cyprus with the rest of the island? A barricade here was removed in 2008 and it became the sixth official crossing between the two zones.
It's not part of the Souls series, but what video game developed by FromSoftware concerns the title ninja taking revenge on the evil Isshin Ashina?
Which textile is made from cotton in a twill weave and is popular for making trousers for, say, work use? Its name comes from Spanish and reflects the fact it was originally made in China.
The Aquatics Centre at Stratford, first built for the 2012 London Olympics, was designed by which Baghdad-born architect, the first female winner of the Pritzker Prize?

Answer: White-tailed eagle (accept sea eagle, Haliaeetus albicilla, ern)
Question: Which species is Britain's largest bird of prey? In 2019, six of these birds were released in the Isle of Wight, where they had last bred in 1780.
Which member of Little Mix, who were formed on The X Factor in 2011, left the band in 2020? She has spoken openly about the impact of cyber-bullying and her body image issues.
Beginning with a C, what online car dealership is the kit sponsor of the England men's test cricket team? It also sponsors the Scottish Football League and the sleeves of Spurs.
What was the name, meaning 'left-handed hummingbird', of the Aztec deity of war, sun and human sacrifice, and the patron of the city of Tenochtitlan?
What term, commonly contrasted with conduction and radiation, describes the transfer of heat due to the movement of a fluid?
Which English new wave band whose vocals were provided by Anna Maria had its only UK top 40 hit in 1982 with Drowning in Berlin?
Founded in San Francisco in 2006, what streaming service focuses on streaming anime and manga series? The service was bought by Funimation, a subsidiary of Sony, in December 2020.
Named after a Biblical character, what name was given to rioting by agricultural workers in west and mid-Wales between 1839 and '43, in protest at unfair taxation?

Tonbridge, Maidstone and Rochester are towns on which river in Kent? According to local lore, people born to its west are called 'Kentish men or maids' and people born to its east are called 'men or maids of Kent'.
Only 20 players have played at least 300 first-team games for two different English clubs. One was which English goalkeeper who did so for both Liverpool and Spurs between 1967 and 1988?
Nicknames for which US jazz singer included the First Lady of Song, Queen of Jazz, and Lady Ella?
Which Russian word meaning 'east' was given to the Soviet space programme which ran between 1961 and '63 and succeeded, among other things, in putting the first human – Yuri Gagarin – into space?

Which medication, intended to treat diseases caused by roundworms and ectoparasites, has been the subject of unfounded rumours by conspiracy theorists that it can be used to treat COVID-19? Some people have suffered damage after ingesting extra-strong versions intended for use on horses and other livestock.

Which Radio 4 current affairs programme is broadcast from 6am to 9am on weekday mornings and from 7am to 9am on Saturday? In 2021, Amol Rajan succeeded Martha Kearney as host of this show, which is considered to be important in setting the political news agenda.
Which Spanish player won her only Wimbledon Ladies' Singles, and indeed only Grand Slam singles tournament overall, at the 1994 event?

What two-word phrase did Adam Smith use to describe the beneficial social and economic outcomes that may arise from the accumulated self-interested actions of individuals, none of whom intends to bring about such outcomes?
What alliterative woman's name was the title of Booth Tarkington's 1921 novel, for which he won the Pulitzer Prize?
Which American stand-up comedian and Saturday Night Live cast member was briefly engaged to Ariana Grande in 2018?
Which durable textile has distinctive ridges? A popular but false etymology claims its name derives from the French for 'cord of the king'.
The ArcelorMittal Orbit observation tower at Stratford, first built for the 2012 London Olympics, was co-designed by which Mumbai-born sculptor, who also won the 1991 Turner Prize?

In 2020, the Knepp estate in West Sussex saw the white species of which very large, migratory species of bird breed for the first time in Britain since 1416? In continental Europe they are known for their large nests often built on manmade structures.
Which member of Fifth Harmony, who were formed on the American version of The X Factor in 2012, left the band in 2016 and has gone on to have a successful solo career, with singles including Havana?

Lydia West and Olly Alexander starred in which 2021 Russell T. Davies drama series which takes its name from a Pet Shop Boys single? It follows the lives of several gay men in London during the HIV/AIDS crisis.

Along with its sister ship the Musashi, which Japanese battleship of World War II remains the largest ever constructed? After serving as the Japanese flagship at the Battle of Midway, it was sunk on its way to Okinawa in 1945.

Which tourist quarter of Famagusta in northern Cyprus was deserted in 1974 after the Turkish invasion and has since become a ghost town, its decaying buildings overgrown with vegetation? Parts of it were reopened to the public in 2020 and 2021.
It's not part of the Souls series, but what video game developed by FromSoftware concerns a Hunter travelling through the cursed land of Yharnam?

What word precedes "Dances" to give the name of a set of 16 orchestral pieces by Antonín Dvořák? They evoke the style and spirit of folk music from the composer's native Bohemia, including dances such as the polka, mazurka and polonaise?

One of several techniques for solving the phase problem in x-ray crystallography, what adjective does the A stand for in the technique MAD, if the D stands for dispersion and the M stands for multi-wavelength? This technique involves analysing the phase shift which occurs when electrons absorb and then re-emit x-rays of particular wavelengths.

What five-letter adjective precedes "man" in the expression used by then Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith to describe himself at the 2002 Conservative Party conference? He repeated it the following year, claiming he was "here to stay and turning up the volume" a month before he resigned as leader.
Which 1993 period drama starring Richard Gere and Jodie Foster was a remake of 1982 French film The Return of Martin Guerre?

Which city in the north-eastern Netherlands has been the site of that country's Grand Prix motorcycle race every year since the series was created in 1949? Fabio Quartararo was the 2021 winner at the track.
Which of the 'Seven Summits' is the highest point in North America? You may give the name given to it in 2015, or its name before that, which was that of an assassinated President.

Sonnets on Death is a work by which Chilean poet-diplomat, who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1945? She is said to have taken her professional surname from that of an Occitan writer with the forename Frederic who won the Nobel Literature Prize in 1904.

New England and West Coast are common variants of what style of beer? The full name of this style, which is noted for its hoppiness, references its early success being exported to cities like Calcutta and Madras (as they were then called).
Which German player won his only Wimbledon Men's Singles, and indeed only Grand Slam singles tournament overall, at the 1991 event?

First introduced by William Forster Lloyd, which four-word economic concept refers to a situation in which the invisible hand fails to work? In this scenario, individuals cause depletion of a resource to which they have unregulated access by acting in their own self-interest.
What alliterative girl's name was the title of Gwendolyn Brooks' 1949 poetry collection, for which she became the first African-American to win a Pulitzer Prize?
Which American comedian, who co-anchors Weekend Update on Saturday Night Live with Michael Che, married Scarlett Johansson in 2020?
Depicted by Andra Day in a 2021 biopic, which US jazz singer's nickname was Lady Day?
Which Russian word meaning 'peace' was given to the Soviet and Russian space station which operated from 1986 to 2001? The first Briton in space, Helen Sharman, visited this space station in 1991.

In March 2020 Donald Trump suggested that which antimalarial drug, which can also be used to treat some auto-immune conditions, could be used as a COVID-19 treatment, something later shown to be without any scientific basis?

Which scripted slot on the Today programme on Radio 4 is broadcast at around 7.45am and offers "reflections from a faith perspective on issues and people in the news"? Contributors have included Rowan Williams, Pope Benedict XVI, and Giles Fraser.
Founded in 2015 by AMC Networks, what video-on-demand service focuses almost exclusively on horror and supernatural media?

What name was given to rioting in 1830 by agricultural workers in Kent in protest at mechanisation and poor working conditions? This name followed the title 'Captain' in the name of a fictitious character who signed letters in support of the rioters' aims.

Men or maids of Kent may have been born on or near which river in Kent which flows through Ashford, Sandwich and Canterbury? It shares its name with different rivers in Dorset, the Midlands and Suffolk.
Another footballer who played at least 300 first-team games for two different English clubs was which Northern Irish goalkeeper who did so for both Spurs and Arsenal between 1964 and 1986?
Beginning with a C, what online car dealership is the primary sponsor of The Hundred? It also sponsors the Rugby League World Cup and is Everton's main shirt sponsor.
The shape of the bass clef is derived from that of which letter, representing a musical note? The two dots of the clef appear either side of the second line from the top of the stave.

In the 1930s, Mary Cartwright and John Littlewood pioneered the study of what 'effect', a central concept in chaos theory? The effect is named after an animal, whose wing movements are typically used to exemplify it.
One of the five 'Monuments' of one-day cycling is a tour of which Flemish-speaking northern portion of Belgium?

In 1983, Guy Laliberté co-founded which Canadian entertainment company, regarded as the world's largest contemporary circus producer? It hosts multiple nightly shows in Las Vegas as well as elsewhere in the world.

Answer: Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi (both required)
Question: The second and fourth most-liked posts on Instagram are of the same image, which depicts which two famous sportspeople playing chess in an advert for Louis Vuitton?
Which Scottish author wrote the 1841 work Extraordinary Popular Delusions and the Madness of Crowds, the first major study discussing crowd psychology?

What name, also the byname of the Holy Roman Emperor Frederick I, was given to the invasion of Russia by Nazi Germany, which commenced in June 1941? Germany made rapid initial advances but was ultimately repelled by Russia.

Cenni di Pepi was the name of which 13th-century Italian painter, regarded as the first to break from the Italo-Byzantine painting tradition? Vasari claimed this painter was the teacher of Giotto, but that is now regarded as uncertain.

What word, from the Greek for 'conclusion', describes a type of argument in deductive reasoning in which a conclusion is drawn from a major and a minor premise? "All men are mortal; Socrates is a man; therefore, Socrates is mortal" is a famous example of this kind of argument.

What name is given to the groups of far-left radical communists that formed after the 1967 split of the Communist Party of India (Marxist)? Named after a 1967 uprising in West Bengal, these Maoist groups continue to fight a conflict with the Indian state.
Which British biologist coined the term 'evolutionarily stable strategy'? He was the first to apply game theory to evolutionary biology and wrote Evolution and the Theory of Games.

Which racetrack in northern California, which closed in 2008, hosted the notorious 1969 free concert that saw an audience member, Meredith Hunter, stabbed to death by a member of the Hell's Angels as the Rolling Stones played their set?
Which Batman villain has been depicted on screen by Burgess Meredith, Danny De Vito and Colin Farrell?

Which Nintendo console was released in 2006 and came bundled with a sports simulation video game named [This console] Sports? Tennis, baseball and golf are among the sports playable in this best-selling Nintendo title of all time.

What name of Afrikaans derivation is given to the eastern portion of the Great Escarpment in southern Africa, and particularly the sections of it that contain the borders between Lesotho and Eastern Cape and then KwaZulu-Natal?
The Bacillus Calmette–Guérin, or BCG, vaccine is primarily used against which illness?
By what name was the Olympic swimmer Sharron Davies known on the TV series Gladiators?
